greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct prime divisors of 44...441 (with n 4s).
comment: There are very few primes in this sequence. 41 appears as the smallest prime divisor frequently. There are many semiprimes.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..199
Dario Alpern, Factorization using the Elliptic Curve Method
example: The number of distinct prime divisors of 441 is 2.
The number of distinct prime divisors of 44444444444444444444444444444441 is four.
mathematica: f[n_] := Length@ FactorInteger[(4*10^(n + 1) - 31)/9]; Array[f, 105] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 09 2010 *)
results.author: _Parthasarathy Nambi_, Apr 21 2005, extended Aug 08 2010
ext: a(32) - a(105) from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 09 2010
